q: What should I do if a chemical gets into my eye?
i: If a strong chemical, such as oven cleaner or bleach, is in your eye, you should keep rinsing your eye with water while waiting for medical help.

q: What immediate action should I take if an object pierces my eye?
i: If a sharp object has pierced your eye, you should go to A&E or call 999 immediately.
a: If a sharp object has pierced your eye, you should go to A&E or call 999 immediately.

q: How should I treat an eye injury at home?
i: If there's something in your eye, you should wash it with clean water. If any cosmetics or household products get in your eyes, follow the advice on the packaging. You can also take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen to help ease any pain or discomfort.

q: What should I not do when treating an eye injury at home?
i: When treating an eye injury at home, you should not try to remove any object that's pierced your eye, touch or rub your eye until it's better, wear make-up around your eye until it's better, or wear contact lenses until your eye is better.

q: How should I wash my eye?
a: To wash your eye, you should use clean water (not hot) and hold your eye open. Run lots of water over your eyeball for at least 20 minutes, making sure the flow of water is not too strong.

q: When should I ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 for an eye injury?
i: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if your eye injury is not getting better after 24 hours or if you're worried about the injury.

q: Where can I get advice for an eye injury?
a: You can call NHS 111 or visit an opticians for advice on your eye injury.

q: When do minor eye injuries typically get better?
a: Minor eye injuries, such as shampoo or dust in your eye, often get better on their own within a day.
